questions.question: What was Mathilde's problem as explained by the narrator?

choices.answer: She was selfish but loved her husband.
She wants to go to fancy parties every day.
She has low self-esteem.
She was born into the wrong level of society.

questions.question: What is the main source of Mathilde's envy?

choices.answer: She feels she was born for the wealthier life with more glamorous items.
Her friend, Mme. Forestier, encourages her to betray her husband.
Her husband is just a mid level employee despite his love for her.
She has beauty and wealth but wants more wealth.

questions.question: Why does Mathilde borrow a necklace from her friend Mme. Forestier?

choices.answer: She doesn't want to risk losing her real diamonds.
She doesn't have real jewels and doesn't want to look poor.
Her husband is allergic to flowers.
Mme. Forestier insists that she wear this diamond necklace to fit in.

questions.question: Why don't the Loisels tell Mme. Forestier what happened to the necklace?

choices.answer: They are ashamed to admit their mistake and embarrassed.
M. Loisel has a criminal record and doesn't want to be accused.
Mme. Forestier has a mean reputation.
They don't want to replace it with the exact one.

questions.question: How do the Loisels get the funds to replace the necklace?

choices.answer: borrow all of it
borrow $, use savings, and Mathilde gets a full time job
borrow $, work hard, change lifestyle
borrow some and work hard, but do NOT change lifestyle

questions.question: What is Mathilde's best day?

choices.answer: The big reception.
Getting the invitation.
Her wedding.
When Mme. Forestier was fooled with the replacement.

questions.question: What is the greatest irony in the story?

choices.answer: Spending her husband's gun savings on a dress.
Wasting ten years to replace a fake necklace.
Mathilde being born into the wrong class.
Mathilde being accepted as a social elite.

questions.question: What is NOT a possible theme of the story?

choices.answer: Marry only for love.
Be true to yourself and others.
Envy causes misery.
Honesty is the best policy.

questions.question: What is the point of view of the story?

choices.answer: Third person omniscient.
Omniscient.
Third person limited.
First person.

questions.question: What is a reason to believe that Mathilde has not changed internally by the end?

choices.answer: She gets sassy and blames Mme. Forestier for her troubles at the end.
She did tell the truth to Mme. Forestier in the end.
She uses her free time to stroll down a rich shopping street.
She has become old, hardened, and rough looking.

questions.question: What is the best description for M. Loisel?

choices.answer: He is kind, generous, and hard-working.
He would have become very rich if not for Mathilde.
He is kind but only married Mathilde for her looks.
He is kind but becomes angry and bitter.

questions.question: Why didn't Mathilde like visiting her school friend at the beginning of the story?

choices.answer: She was jealous of her husband and children.
She was jealous of everything she had while Mathilde did not.
She was afraid she knew of the fake necklace.
M. Loisel originally asked to marry Forestier.

questions.question: Why does Mathilde run from her husband after the reception?

choices.answer: She didn't want to be seen in inexpensive wraps.
She didn't want to be yelled at by him for dancing with other men.
She didn't want to be seen with her middle class husband.
She wanted to keep the night going and didn't want to go home.

questions.question: What is Mathilde's attitude about the party after ten years?

choices.answer: She never thinks about it again.
She wishes she had never gone to it.
She often dreams about the great event and her popularity.
She often blames her husband for getting the tickets.

questions.question: What is ironic about Mathilde's circumstances during the course of the story?

choices.answer: She daydreams about being rich and ends up with a diamond necklace.
She married for love and her husband hates her by the end.
She daydreams about being elite and ends up poorer than dirt.
She starts middle class and stays there despite her good looks.

questions.question: What part of plot would "running from her husband" be?

choices.answer: Exposition
Rising action
Climax
Falling action

questions.question: What part of plot would "meeting the gorgeous but sad Mathilde" be?

choices.answer: Exposition
Climax
Falling action
Resolution

questions.question: What part of plot would "spending $400 gun savings" be?

choices.answer: Exposition
Rising action
Climax
Resolution

questions.question: What part of plot would "spending $18,000 inheritance" be?

choices.answer: Exposition
Rising Action
Climax
Falling action

questions.question: What part of plot would "it was worth 500 francs at most" be?

choices.answer: Rising action
Climax
Falling action
Resolution
